newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia sets rules for foreign listings on KLSE.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia sets rules for foreign listings on KLSE.

text.p: Only foreign-based firms "with substantial Malaysian interests" would be able to list on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE), under new guidelines issued on Tuesday by the Securities Commission.
The scope of foreign companies which are to list on the KLSE "will be gradually widened in subsequent phases at the appropriate time," the markets watchdog said in a statement.
Malaysia last year announced that it would accept foreign-based listings on the KLSE as part of its campaign to become a regional financial centre.
The Securities Commission statement said only quality foreign listings would be accepted, which have "consistency with government objectives and national economic interests".
The listings would be denominated in ringgit and only primary listings would be allowed.

Special bumiputera ownership requirements would apply to foreign-based companies, the statement said. Thirty percent of a company's ownership must be held by indigenous Malaysians, or Bumiputeras, under current listing requirements.
